study_plan_entry.title: Advanced experimental methods in condensed matter and nanophysics

free_text.Learning outcomes: The objective of the course is to expose PhD students to experimental measurement techniques and principles applied in front end research of condensed matter and nanophysics. The course is a block course of lectures with integrated lab instructions (36 hours) taking place during one week at the Max-Planck-Institute for Solid State Research in Stuttgart, Germany. Besides providing a solid background, it will focus on the crucial details which will make cutting edge experiments work, details which are usually not taught in text books
free_text.Content: - Introduction[br/]- Solids at the nanoscale[br/]- Nanostructure fabrication: physical and chemical methods[br/]- Matter at low temperatures, ultrahigh vacuum, low signal amplification[br/]- Actuators and transducers as experimental tools[br/]- Electronic transport[br/]- Microscopy with atomic resolution: from electron microscopy to scannig probes[br/]- Optics at the nanoscale[br/]- Excitation spectroscopy: from electron spectroscopy to synchrotron based approaches[br/]
free_text.Keywords: Advanced experimental methods, condensed matter physics, nanophysics
free_text.Note: PhD students from EPFL will be accommodated in the guest house of the Max-Planck-Institute. The number of Lausanne participants is limited to ten per course.[br/][br/]Block course: at the Max-Planck-Institute for Solid State Research in Stuttgart
